chat_history.content: : Welcome to Conceptual Academy! I'm Alia, and I'm here to support the learning of core science concepts. Let's get started. How can I help you today?
: Hi Alia. I need to understand something about how matter is classified in chemistry. I've always struggled with science classes, so I'm a bit nervous about this topic.

: That's completely understandable! Many students feel that way at first. Today we can explore how matter is classified as pure or impure from a chemist's perspective. Would that be helpful for your studies?
: Yes, that would be great. I guess my first question is - what exactly does a chemist mean when they talk about something being "pure"?

: From a chemist's point of view, if a material is pure, it consists of only a single element or a single compound. In pure gold, for example, there is nothing but the element gold. In pure table salt, there is nothing but the compound sodium chloride. If a material is impure, it is a mixture and contains two or more elements or compounds.
: So wait, when I buy "pure orange juice" at the store, a chemist wouldn't consider that pure at all?

: That's exactly right! Sometimes naturally occurring mixtures are labeled as being pure, as in "pure orange juice." Such a statement means that nothing artificial has been added. According to a chemist's definition, however, orange juice is anything but pure, as it contains a wide variety of materials, including water, pulp, flavorings, vitamins, and sugars.
: That's interesting! So pure has different meanings depending on who's using the term?

: Yes! Outside the language of chemistry, sometimes a mixture can be identified as pure. A cook, for example, might ask for pure baking powder. To a chemist, however, this doesn't make sense because baking powder is a mixture of baking soda and sodium aluminum sulfate, plus many other chemicals.
: I'm curious - how pure can something actually be? Is anything 100% pure?

: That's a thoughtful question. Because atoms and molecules are so small, there is a countless number of them in even a tiny sample. If just one atom or molecule out of many were different, then this sample could not be classified as 100 percent pure. Samples can be "purified," however, by various methods, such as distillation. When we say pure, it is understood to be a relative term.
: So it's more about comparing the purity levels between samples?

: Exactly. Comparing the purity of two samples, the purer one contains fewer impurities. A sample of water that is 99.9 percent pure has a greater proportion of impurities than does a sample of water that is 99.9999 percent pure. The 99.9999 percent pure water would be much more expensive, because this high degree of purity is rather difficult to attain.
: Ok, I think I'm getting the classification part. So chemists divide matter into pure substances and mixtures. What about mixtures - are there different types?

: Yes, mixtures may be heterogeneous or homogeneous. In a heterogeneous mixture, the different components can be seen as individual substances, such as pulp in orange juice, sand in water, or oil globules dispersed in vinegar. The different components are visible.
: And homogeneous mixtures? Are those where everything looks the same throughout?

: That's right! Homogeneous mixtures have the same composition throughout as judged by the unaided eye. Any one region of the mixture has the same ratio of substances as does any other region. The reason for this is because the different components are mixed at a very fine level such that the components cannot be seen as individual identifiable entities.
: So like if I dissolved sugar in water completely, that would be homogeneous because I can't see the sugar anymore?
: Yes, that's a perfect example! Once the sugar is completely dissolved, you can't distinguish the sugar from the water with your eyes. Every part of the solution would taste equally sweet.
: Are there different types of homogeneous mixtures too?

: Yes, a homogeneous mixture may be either a solution or a suspension. In a solution, all components are in the same phase. The atmosphere we breathe is a gaseous solution consisting of the gaseous elements nitrogen and oxygen as well as minor amounts of other gaseous materials. Salt water is a liquid solution, because both the water and the dissolved sodium chloride are found in a single liquid phase. An example of a solid solution is white gold.
: Oh, I didn't know white gold was a mixture! What exactly is it?

: White gold is a mixture of gold with smaller amounts of white metals, such as silver, palladium, or rhodium, that increase its hardness. Unlike gold, the precious metal platinum is used in jewelry in almost its pure form, about 95 percent. Platinum is a very white metal and is also very dense. A platinum ring will feel heavier than a typical yellow or white gold ring, but it will also be much more expensive.
: That's fascinating! Now I understand why platinum jewelry costs so much more. What about suspensions? How are they different from solutions?

: A suspension forms when the particles of a substance are finely mixed but not dissolved. The components of a suspension can be of different phases, such as solid particles suspended within a liquid or liquid droplets suspended within a gas. In a suspension, the mixing can be so thorough that the different phases are not readily distinguished.
: Can you give me some examples of suspensions I might encounter in everyday life?

: Absolutely! Milk is a suspension because it is a homogeneous mixture of proteins and fats finely dispersed in water. Blood is a suspension composed of finely dispersed blood cells in water. Another example of a suspension is clouds, which are homogeneous mixtures of tiny water droplets suspended in air.
: Those are great examples! Is there a way to tell if something is a suspension or a solution just by looking at it?

: Sometimes it can be difficult to distinguish just by looking. One interesting feature of suspensions is that light shining through a suspension results in a visible cone as the light is reflected by the suspended components. But the easiest way to distinguish a suspension from a solution in the laboratory is to spin a sample in a centrifuge.
: A centrifuge? That's the spinning machine, right? How does that help?

: Yes, a centrifuge is a device that spins at thousands of revolutions per minute. It separates the components of suspensions but not those of solutions. For example, blood, because it is a suspension, can be centrifuged into its components, which include the blood plasma (a yellowish solution) and white and red blood cells. The components of the plasma cannot be separated from one another because a centrifuge has no effect on solutions.
: That makes sense. So if I can separate it by spinning, it's a suspension. If not, it's a solution. Wait - if blood plasma is a solution, does that mean it's pure?

: That's a good question, but no. Notice that blood plasma, white blood cells, and red blood cells can be isolated from blood. None of these components of blood, however, are in themselves pure materials. The plasma contains many dissolved substances.
: I think I'm a bit confused about purification. If I have impure water, how do I make it pure?

: Impure water can be purified by removing everything that isn't water. H₂O is a compound made of the elements hydrogen and oxygen in a 2-to-1 ratio. Every H₂O molecule is the same as every other, and there's no such thing as an impure H₂O molecule. Just about anything, including you, beach balls, rubber ducks, dust particles, and bacteria, can be found in water. When something other than water is found in water, we say that the water is impure.
: Oh, I see! So the water molecules themselves are always pure, but the sample of water might contain other stuff mixed in.

: Exactly! It is important to see that the impurities are in the water and not part of the water, which means that it is possible to remove them by a variety of physical means, such as filtration or distillation.
: I'm starting to understand this better. But I'm curious - how pure can something really get? Like, if we say water is 99.9999% pure, what does that actually mean in terms of molecules?

: That's an excellent question that leads us to an interesting calculation about purity. A 100-gram sample of water contains about 3 × 10²⁴ molecules. If this sample were ideally pure, every one of those molecules would be water. Atoms and molecules, however, are so amazingly small, and hence numerous, that the formation of a truly pure sample of macroscopic quantity is virtually impossible.
: Wow, that's a huge number of molecules!

: Indeed it is! For example, consider a 100-gram sample of water that is 99.9999 percent pure. What this means is that the sample contains 99.9999 grams of water, which is still nearly 3 × 10²⁴ water molecules. Pretty good, right? However, if the remaining 0.0001 grams were made of dissolved lead, Pb, then this would correspond to about 3 × 10¹⁷ (300,000 trillion) atoms of Pb, which is quite small compared to the number of water molecules but is still an amazingly large number.
: That's mind-blowing! So even when something is incredibly pure by our standards, it still contains trillions of impurity molecules or atoms?

: That's right! Any material that is seemingly pure will inevitably contain impurities. Sometimes these impurities are of particular interest. For example, minor impurities in a solution might be toxic and their presence might need to be monitored. How much is present is frequently measured in units of milligrams per liter (mg/L), micrograms per liter (μg/L), or nanograms per liter (ng/L) of solution.
: I think I've heard of parts per million before. Is that related to these measurements?

: Yes, absolutely! One liter of water contains one million milligrams of water. Because 1 L of water equals 1 million mg of water, the units of mg/L can also be expressed as 1 mg per 1 million mg. Another way of saying this is one part per million, or simply 1 ppm. The units of mg/L and ppm, therefore, are equivalent.
: And I'm guessing there are smaller concentrations too?

: Yes, similarly, "micrograms per liter" is often expressed as parts per billion, ppb, and "nanograms per liter" is often expressed as parts per trillion, ppt. Remember that 1 milligram equals 1000 micrograms, while 1 microgram equals 1000 nanograms.
: Can you walk me through an example of how to calculate this? I've never been great at math.

: Of course! Here's an example: There are about 35 grams of salts in every liter of ocean water. To express this concentration in units of ppm, we need to convert grams of salt into milligrams of salt.

First, we multiply: (35 g salts)(1000 mg/1g) = 35,000 mg

So there are about 35,000 mg of salts in a liter of ocean water, which equals 35,000 ppm.
: That doesn't seem so bad! So ocean water is 35,000 parts per million salt. That helps me visualize how salty the ocean really is.
: Exactly! Would you like to try a problem yourself to practice?
: Sure, I can try. Maybe start with something simple?
: Here's one: Typical levels of fluoride found in fluoridated public drinking water are about 1.0 ppm. If you were to drink a liter of this water, how many milligrams of fluoride would you ingest?
: Ok, let me think... If ppm means parts per million, and that's the same as mg/L, then 1.0 ppm would be 1.0 mg/L. So if I drink a liter, I'd ingest 1 milligram of fluoride. Is that right?

: That's perfect! You've got it. Here's another one: Aquatic organisms require a dissolved oxygen concentration of about 6 ppm. At this concentration, how many grams of oxygen are present in each liter of water?
: Hmm, so 6 ppm means 6 mg/L. And to convert to grams, I divide by 1000 since there are 1000 mg in a gram. So that would be 0.006 grams of oxygen per liter. This is starting to make sense!

: Excellent work! You're really getting the hang of this. Let's try one more: Chloroform, CHCl₃, is a common contaminant of chlorinated drinking water. A usual concentration in municipal tap water may be around 25 ppb. At this concentration, how many milligrams of chloroform are present in each liter of water?

: Ok, so ppb is parts per billion, which would be μg/L. So 25 ppb means 25 μg/L. And to convert to milligrams, I divide by 1000 since there are 1000 μg in a mg. So that's 0.025 milligrams per liter. I'm actually getting this!
: You're doing wonderfully! These concentration units help us understand just how dilute some substances can be in our water while still being detectable and potentially significant.
: This has been really eye-opening. I never realized how precise chemistry could be, measuring things in such tiny amounts. It makes me think differently about what "pure" really means.

: That's a great insight! Here's one last thought experiment: Assume that the population of the United States is 330 million. Each U.S. citizen would have a concentration of 3.0 ppb. Assume a world human population of 8 billion. Each human would have a concentration of 125 ppt. If you can imagine how small in number you are compared to national or world populations, then you have a sense of how dilute a dissolved substance is when its concentration is measured by the ppb or ppt.

: Wow! That really puts it in perspective. I'm just one in 330 million Americans, and that's only 3 parts per billion. That helps me visualize just how incredibly small these concentrations are. I think I actually understand this whole pure/impure matter classification now! Thanks, Alia!

: You're very welcome! You've made excellent progress today. Remember, in chemistry, pure means consisting of only a single element or compound, while impure materials are mixtures containing two or more elements or compounds. And even what we consider "pure" still contains an incredibly large number of molecules with some impurities. Is there anything else about this topic you'd like to explore?
: I think I'm good for now. I feel much more confident about this chapter. Chemistry isn't as intimidating as I thought it would be!

: That's wonderful to hear! You've demonstrated a great ability to connect these concepts to everyday examples, which is extremely helpful in science learning. Feel free to come back anytime you have questions about your chemistry studies!
